comment._content: Guests at a New York City costume party, January, 1914. In 1914, Rea Irvin already had a reputation as a New York bon vivant. A comic artist for Red Book magazine, in that year he illustrated numerous Red Book stories written by the humorist Ellis Parker Butler (who is now best remembered for his story, "Pigs Is Pigs.) Before WWI, Irvin also contributed a steady stream of illustrations to the old "Life" magazine, a humor weekly. Irvin in 1925 became the first art editor of a new magazine, "The New Yorker," for which he designed the first cover, a portrait of Eustace Tilley, the supercilious Regency fop who became the magazine's symbol. Tilley's pose is parodied here: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/idogcow/4289390151/] Rea Irvin's Wikipedia bio: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rea_Irvin
